intro: Melandrium affine, commonly known as the common sand-verbena, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family and is characterized by its upright growth habit and clusters of small, pinkish-white flowers. The plant typically blooms in late spring to early summer, producing delicate, five-petaled flowers that attract pollinators. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in dry, sandy or rocky habitats. Melandrium affine is a perennial herb that can reach heights of up to 30 centimeters, with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves.
